item.title: cot²θ + 1 = csc²θ
item.description:
Let’s prove the identity step by step.

\[ \cot^2{\theta} + 1 = \csc^2{\theta} \]

Step-by-Step Proof:

  1. Express in Terms of Sine and Cosine:

    • Recall that: \[ \cot{\theta} = \frac{\cos{\theta}}{\sin{\theta}} \] \[ \csc{\theta} = \frac{1}{\sin{\theta}} \]
  2. \[ \cot^2{\theta} = \left(\frac{\cos{\theta}}{\sin{\theta}}\right)^2 = \frac{\cos^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} \]
  3. \[ \cot^2{\theta} + 1 = \frac{\cos^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} + 1 \]

  4. Find a Common Denominator to Combine Terms:

    • To add \( \frac{\cos^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} \) and 1, express 1 as \( \frac{\sin^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} \): \[ \frac{\cos^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} + 1 = \frac{\cos^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} + \frac{\sin^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} \]
  5. \[ \frac{\cos^2{\theta} + \sin^2{\theta}}{\sin^2{\theta}} \]

item.title: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
item.description:
To prove the identity \(\sin^2\theta + \cos^2\theta = 1\), we can use the unit circle definition of sine and cosine:

  1. Unit Circle Approach:

    • On the unit circle (radius \( r = 1 \)), any point is represented as \( (\cos\theta, \sin\theta) \).
    • The distance from this point to the origin is calculated using the Pythagorean theorem: \[ (\cos\theta)^2 + (\sin\theta)^2 = 1^2 \]
    • Simplifying, we get: \[ \sin^2\theta + \cos^2\theta = 1 \]

item.title: tan²θ + 1 = sec²θ
item.description:
Let’s break down the proof step by step.

Given:
We want to show that \(\tan^{2}(\theta) + 1 = \sec^{2}(\theta)\).

\[ \tan(\theta) = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)} \]\[ \tan^{2}(\theta) = \left(\frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}\right)^{2} = \frac{\sin^{2}(\theta)}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} \]\[ \tan^{2}(\theta) + 1 = \frac{\sin^{2}(\theta)}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} + 1 \]\[ 1 = \frac{\cos^{2}(\theta)}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} \]\[ \tan^{2}(\theta) + 1 = \frac{\sin^{2}(\theta) + \cos^{2}(\theta)}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} \]\[ \tan^{2}(\theta) + 1 = \frac{1}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} \]\[ \left(\frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}\right)^{2} = \frac{1}{\cos^{2}(\theta)} \]\[ \tan^{2}(\theta) + 1 = \sec^{2}(\theta) \]

This completes the proof that \(\tan^{2}(\theta) + 1\) equals \(\sec^{2}(\theta)\).
